(1) Franklin Street, west from, but not including Baxter Street. The view shows the "Bridge of Sighs" connecting the Tombs, with the Criminal Court Building on the right.
September 24, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, from a different angle.
February 24, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same, showing a closer view of said bridge, west from Centre Street.
February 24, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) White Street, west from but not including Baxter Street.
September 24, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, at a later date. February 25, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) A view of the lower portion of No. 131-33 White Street (also bears No. 76-82 Baxter Street) being at the S.W. corner, as shown on the left of Views 1 and 2. This will be included in the demolition necessitated by plans for the new Criminal Courts Building and will form the northeastern corner of same.

November 6, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

White Street, north side, from Baxter (right) to Centre (left) Streets, as viewed northward across the cleared site for the new Criminal Courts (and prison) Bldg. This incorporates two square blocks which have just been cleared and are bounded by Centre, east to Baxter, and Leonard, north to White Streets. Thru the center runs Franklin Street. The photographers vantage point in No. 1 is Leonard Street, while in No.2 he is on Baxter Street. To the left in the latter instance, is Columbus Park.

June 10, 1938.
View 2: June 12, 1938

P. L. Sperr

White Street, north side, from Baxter (right) to Centre (left) Streets, as viewed northward across the cleared site for the new Criminal Courts (and prison) Bldg. This incorporates two square blocks which have just been cleared and are bounded by Centre, east to Baxter, and Leonard, north to White Streets. Thru the center runs Franklin Street. The photographers vantage point in No. 1 is Leonard Street, while in No.2 he is on Baxter Street. To the left in the latter instance, is Columbus Park.

June 10, 1938.
View 2: June 12, 1938

P. L. Sperr

(1)
Baxter Street, north from and including Franklin Street. Part of Columbus Park is seen in the foreground.
March 27, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, a more inclusive view. Shown on the far side of Columbus Park is the north side of Bayard Street, east to Mulberry Street.
March 27, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Baxter Street, north from and including Franklin Street. Part of Columbus Park is seen in the foreground.
March 27, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, a more inclusive view. Shown on the far side of Columbus Park is the north side of Bayard Street, east to Mulberry Street.
March 27, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(1 & 2)

Columbus Park: A set of 2 views showing the upper half of same as viewed northward from the New York State Office Building. Shown, forming the boundaries of same, are Baxter (left) Mulberry (right) and Bayard (center) Streets. It was this area that formed the famous Five Points.

March 27, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)

A more complete view of this public improvement, as seen from the southern edge, Worth Street (right foreground).

November 6, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(1 & 2)

Columbus Park: A set of 2 views showing the upper half of same as viewed northward from the New York State Office Building. Shown, forming the boundaries of same, are Baxter (left) Mulberry (right) and Bayard (center) Streets. It was this area that formed the famous Five Points.

March 27, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)

A more complete view of this public improvement, as seen from the southern edge, Worth Street (right foreground).

November 6, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(1 & 2)

(3)

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Feast of San Rocco (St. Roch), 1932, No. 7. Paraders, a group of children and others, at 98-100 Bayard Street near the corner of Baxter Street.

August 16, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
No. 8. A larger view of the same scene, showing an elaborate candelabrum borne by four young women. This view shows the end of western end of Bayard Street, at Baxter Street.

August 16, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
No. 9. A group of children who have been in the procession. Notice the number of angels.

August 16, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Feast of San Rocco [Saint Roch].

text:
(1)
Baxter Street, west side, north from Franklin and across White Streets, showing in the foreground a block of buildings that will be demolished. Upon their site will rise the new Criminal Courts Building.
November 6, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A detail of same, showing Nos. 70, 68, 66 and 64 (right to left). The last two are at the N.W. and S.W. corners of Franklin Street, respectively. Photographers vantage point is at Bayard Street; the northern confine of Columbus Park (left).
November 6, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
Nos. 72 and 74 Baxter Street, as viewed westward on Bayard Street.
November 6, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

64 Baxter Street, at the S.W. corner of Franklin Street (right). This structure, also bearing No. 1 Franklin Street, will be demolished shortly and form a portion of the new site of the proposed Criminal Courts Building.

November 6, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

66 Baxter Street (right) at the N.W. corner of Franklin Street (left) showing a structure that will shortly be demolished as a portion of the site for the new Criminal Courts Building.

November 6, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Franklin Street, west from Baxter Street and showing in the foreground, on both sides, the buildings that will be demolished to provide a site for the new Criminal Courts Building; replacing the bridged structures shown between Centre and Lafayette Streets. This is a set of three views; No. 2 of which shows only the south side of the block between Baxter and Centre Streets.

November 6, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Franklin Street, west from Baxter Street and showing in the foreground, on both sides, the buildings that will be demolished to provide a site for the new Criminal Courts Building; replacing the bridged structures shown between Centre and Lafayette Streets. This is a set of three views; No. 2 of which shows only the south side of the block between Baxter and Centre Streets.

November 6, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Franklin Street, west from Baxter Street and showing in the foreground, on both sides, the buildings that will be demolished to provide a site for the new Criminal Courts Building; replacing the bridged structures shown between Centre and Lafayette Streets. This is a set of three views; No. 2 of which shows only the south side of the block between Baxter and Centre Streets.

November 6, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Baxter Street, west side, at Franklin Street, as viewed south-westward from Bayard Street (left foreground) and showing two complete blocks of buildings, under demolition for the new Criminal Courts Bldg. and prison. To the left and across the partially demolished structures appears a portion of the New York State Bldg. and the tower of the Woolworth Bldg. View 2 is westward on Bayard Street to show the adjacent structures that would be on the right of No. 1. To the left in this view are tenements on the north side of Bayard Street that face Columbus Park. The latter is on the left, though not seen.

March 11, 1938
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr,

Baxter Street, west side, at Franklin Street, as viewed south-westward from Bayard Street (left foreground) and showing two complete blocks of buildings, under demolition for the new Criminal Courts Bldg. and prison. To the left and across the partially demolished structures appears a portion of the New York State Bldg. and the tower of the Woolworth Bldg. View 2 is westward on Bayard Street to show the adjacent structures that would be on the right of No. 1. To the left in this view are tenements on the north side of Bayard Street that face Columbus Park. The latter is on the left, though not seen.

March 11, 1938
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr,

Foley Square (prominent buildings there upon), showing mainly the northerly side of the New York State Bldg., as viewed southward across the new site for the Criminal Courts (and prison) Bldg. This particular side is on the south side of Leonard Street; Center Street being on the extreme right of this panoramic set of three. Across the roof of this structure appear the towers of the Federal Courts Bldg. and the Municipal Bldg.; all fronting on the easterly side of Foley Square. The clearance seen extends for 2 blocks, incorporating an area bounded by White (foreground), Center (right), Leonard and Baxter (left) Streets. On the opposite side of the latter appears a tenement at the N.E. corner of Bayard and Baxter Streets and Columbus Park at the S.E. corner.

June 12, 1938.
Views 1,2 and 3

P. L. Sperr

Foley Square (prominent buildings there upon), showing mainly the northerly side of the New York State Bldg., as viewed southward across the new site for the Criminal Courts (and prison) Bldg. This particular side is on the south side of Leonard Street; Center Street being on the extreme right of this panoramic set of three. Across the roof of this structure appear the towers of the Federal Courts Bldg. and the Municipal Bldg.; all fronting on the easterly side of Foley Square. The clearance seen extends for 2 blocks, incorporating an area bounded by White (foreground), Center (right), Leonard and Baxter (left) Streets. On the opposite side of the latter appears a tenement at the N.E. corner of Bayard and Baxter Streets and Columbus Park at the S.E. corner.

June 12, 1938.
Views 1,2 and 3

P. L. Sperr

Foley Square (prominent buildings there upon), showing mainly the northerly side of the New York State Bldg., as viewed southward across the new site for the Criminal Courts (and prison) Bldg. This particular side is on the south side of Leonard Street; Center Street being on the extreme right of this panoramic set of three. Across the roof of this structure appear the towers of the Federal Courts Bldg. and the Municipal Bldg.; all fronting on the easterly side of Foley Square. The clearance seen extends for 2 blocks, incorporating an area bounded by White (foreground), Center (right), Leonard and Baxter (left) Streets. On the opposite side of the latter appears a tenement at the N.E. corner of Bayard and Baxter Streets and Columbus Park at the S.E. corner.

June 12, 1938.
Views 1,2 and 3

P. L. Sperr

Franklin Street, west from Baxter Street (immediate foreground) showing beyond the future Criminal Courts Bldg. site, the famous "Bridge of Sighs" connecting the Tombs (left) and the old Court Bldg. The two structures will shortly be demolished and their sites possibly sold to private individuals. These, including the new sites rest upon filled land where prior to about 1812, Collect Pond was; This particular task being New York's first public work program. The photographer is in Columbus Park, near what was formerly the infamous "Five Points".
View 2 is eastward across Lafayette Street, to show the opposite side of the aforementioned covered passageway.

P. L. Sperr,

Franklin Street, west from Baxter Street (immediate foreground) showing beyond the future Criminal Courts Bldg. site, the famous "Bridge of Sighs" connecting the Tombs (left) and the old Court Bldg. The two structures will shortly be demolished and their sites possibly sold to private individuals. These, including the new sites rest upon filled land where prior to about 1812, Collect Pond was; This particular task being New York's first public work program. The photographer is in Columbus Park, near what was formerly the infamous "Five Points".
View 2 is eastward across Lafayette Street, to show the opposite side of the aforementioned covered passageway.

P. L. Sperr,

134-36 and 124-32 White Street, at, adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Baxter Street (right) as viewed northward across a portion of the new Criminal Court site. View No. 2 is northward on Baxter Street from Bayard Street (extreme right) and shows mainly the 6 story structure (No. 134-36) that is directly at the corner.

June 10, 1938.
View 2: June 12, 1938.

P. L. Sperr

134-36 and 124-32 White Street, at, adjoining and west of the N.W. corner of Baxter Street (right) as viewed northward across a portion of the new Criminal Court site. View No. 2 is northward on Baxter Street from Bayard Street (extreme right) and shows mainly the 6 story structure (No. 134-36) that is directly at the corner.

June 10, 1938.
View 2: June 12, 1938.

P. L. Sperr
